author: tersec
content: Latency issues might be even trickier to resolve than bandwidth issues in terms of people from certain regions finding their participation hindered, because at that point it's just speed of light/laws of physics and it doesn't matter how fast the data center connection. Also, harder to measure the effectiveness of/sensitivity to because timing games adapt to them.

author: tersec
content: In terms of what's typically most feasible to brute force, it's first local hardware, then bandwidth, then latency. Sometimes there's just no solution to latency.

author: kolbyml
content:
What impact will decreasing the slot time have on
- hardware requirements
- execution state growth and history growth (EIP-4444's hasn't shipped yet and until it does history growth is a valid concern)
- will it affect attestation?
- if solo builders now have less time to propagate everything, couldn't that lead to more skipped slots/re-orgs
- how does network latency play into all this
- Would decreasing the slot time increase the pressure to limit the amount of stakers etc

I am less aware of potential CL concerns, but I think this summary covers most of the potential bases for concerns if the slot time was decreased from 12s to 8s.

author: ben_a_adams
content: Latency isn't really an issue at 8sec; while there is a speed of light hard stop on latency so it becomes impossible to improve we are far away from that and if you can't do 8secs you also won't be able to play any online game (that isn't turn based)

author: ben_a_adams
content: If you RTT is above 500 ms (semi-broken network); then you have real problems as TCP/IP will start retransmitting as lost packets
